channel.title: Seoul on Every Corner of Korea

item.title: Seoul's first municipal arboretum ‘Hangdong Blue Arboretum’ - Guro-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Hangdong Reservoir and Arboretum

Seoul's first municipal arboretum ‘Hangdong Blue Arboretum’

Guro-gu, Seoul, Korea

It is quite exciting to have an arboretum near the place of life. The city's first municipal arboretum appeared in autumn. It is a green arboretum located in Hang-dong, Guro-gu. It is accessible when you take the town bus from the subway station. There is a quiet reed reservoir and you can walk on the Cosmos Pin train track, making it ideal for feeling autumn.

There are several factors that determine a good arboretum for a family to go to. Once you can find three happy smiles on the children's face, the arboretum is a pretty well-made space. For complex urban people, the arboretum is a place where it can be sunny, wind blowing, learning nature and taking a deep breath. So, it's better if you can go lightly for a while rather than the dense forest hiding in the distance. Even if it is not colorful flowers and autumn leaves, I am happy even if there are only one or two materials to enjoy the changing season. Hangdong Blue Arboretum is a grateful space in that it helps to soothe the tired shoulders of urban people.
Arboretum Ecological River
The Blue Arboretum, which represented the first municipal arboretum, debuted this summer. The combined area of the reservoir and the arboretum is 103,000 square meters. Around Arboretum, the contours of Cheonwangsan and the city are in harmony. It is a space located in Seoul, but the greenery comes before the building forest.
Old railroad tracks beside arboretum
In the former district of Hang-dong, Guro-gu, there were many unlicensed buildings and boardwalks, and the complex was concentrated. The Arboretum, designed as part of the making of green Seoul, contains the sad purpose of preventing the indiscriminate development of the city and creating an eco-friendly ecological space.
Guro Ollegil
Reed Forest and Reservoir in Autumn
The Blue Arboretum is still an ongoing space. The forest is not dense enough to shade, and plants everywhere are not boasting mature leaves. People who visited the arboretum last summer may have had a hard time. Opening the door this year, it's just a step away, so watching the changing process of the arboretum is quite meaningful.
Hangdong Reservoir Reed Forest
The Blue Arboretum has more than 1,700 species of plants and 25 themed gardens including Naeumruru and Sagittarius. Korean herbs are attached to existing herb botanical gardens and aquatic botanical gardens. 'Naraeul' is a place where various deciduous broad-leaved trees are planted, and it is the place where you can get the most of the feeling of the forest in the blue arboretum. 'Namsae Madang', which has 100 foods, is a space where planted edible plants are expressed with the joy of production, fruit, and harvest rather than the splendor of the garden. The ‘Mirnae’, which looks like a dragon moving, has a stream length of 1,000m, and it goes through the thematic gardens and serves as an ecological stream for the arboretum.
Rose Garden 'Dalloc Garden'

The most eye-catching place in the Blue Arboretum is the space where Hangdong Reservoir and Reed Forest are combined. The reservoir has a wide reed forest. As you walk along the wooden deck between the reeds that are taller than the height, the rose garden “Dalloc Garden” is revealed. Even in the deep autumn, the late red blossoms show off in the daloc garden. The view of the reservoir from the shelter in front of the dalok garden provides a deep fall break. The scenery of ducks under the reed forest is relaxing.

Planter stand using concrete wall
Old...
Another space where you can enjoy autumn together with the reed forest is the Hangdong railway lined up next to the arboretum. Although the abandoned railroad is strictly beyond the arboretum fence, this railroad serves as a filial piety to shine the green arboretum. Cosmos road runs side by side on both sides of the track.
In fact, this is the place where you can find the biggest laughter on the faces of children. Older adults are reminiscent of memories. Looking down from the railroad tracks, the panoramic view of the arboretum spreads out and the pastel-tone cosmos glistens without hesitation. In an arboretum, you can't get in and out of a railroad track beyond a fence. You can use either the side entrance of the main gate or the small side gate behind the forest ecology hall at the end of the arboretum.
The Blue Arboretum is not a space that is cut off from the surroundings. Like the railroad and cosmos road, the back of the arboretum is connected to the Guro Olle road and leads to a fairly large forest road. The Blue Arboretum is responsible for the axis of the ecological belt that leads to Mount Cheonwang. If walking in the forest is a bit unfortunate in the arboretum, it is good to spend a leisurely time walking through the forest path here.
Forest Education Center
The spaces all over represent the nature of the blue arboretum. The Forest Education Center, a bizarre building opposite the Arboretum, is an exhibition hall of useful crops around the world and a place dedicated to plant education, such as “Gardening School”. There is a book cafe at the entrance of the Arboretum, and various cultural programs such as movie screening are being held. The planter stands that recycled concrete walls are also eye-catching.
Book cafe in Blue Arboretum
There are no restaurants or stalls in the arboretum. However, you can drink hot drinks, such as 2,000 won coffee, in the cafeteria. Simple food can be brought in, but garbage must be taken back. There is a booth where you can rest everywhere, and pet dogs are allowed. The fact that you have to continue walking on the cement road, except for the wooden deck road, is a pity for urban people who are thirsty. On the weekends, parking spaces are also narrow.
Cosmos Finn old railway
Travel information

Blue Arboretum
Address: 240 Yeondong-ro, Guro-gu, Seoul
Contact: 02-2686-3200
Usage fee: Admission, parking fee temporarily free
Hours of use: 5 am to 10 pm (open year-round)

1.Access

* Self-driving

Seobu Main Road → Gyeongin-ro (to Bucheon) → Gocheokgyo Intersection towards Bucheon → Turn left at Sungkukhoe University

* public transport

Get off at Onsu Station of Subway Lines 1 & 7, and take the Guro 07 Village Bus to the Blue Arboretum.

2. Restaurants around

Songrimga: Hanjeongsik / 398, Gyeongin-ro, Guro-gu / 02-2066-6000

http://www.songlimga.com/

Hanging: Hanwoo / 41, Park-ro, Guro-gu / 02-867-9292

Anti-Dog Aid Tofu: Sundubu / 14, Yeondong-ro 12-gil, Guro-gu / 02-2684-3152

3.Accommodation

Best Western Premier Guro Hotel: 72, Digital-ro 32-gil, Guro-gu / 02-6905-9500

http://www.gurohotel.co.kr/

Sheraton Seoul D Cube City Hotel: 682, Gyeongin-ro, Guro-gu / 02-2211-2000

http://www.sheratonseouldcubecity.co.kr/user/main/MainMgr.do

Europaratel: 142, Saemal-ro 18-gil, Guro-gu / 02-869-7396

item.title: Isle of Art under the shade of a birch tree, Seoul National Museum of Modern Art, Seoul - Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul

Isle of Art under the shade of a birch tree, Seoul National Museum of Modern Art, Seoul

Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea

Difficulty became good news. The National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul, stands on a constrained land, but it stands out. While keeping the historicity of the space, I lowered my body and opened the way. The museum became a road, a square, and an island of art.

Magic wandering
From Gyeongbokgung Intersection, head towards Samcheong-dong. The fence on the east side of Gyeongbokgung Palace is a side by side path. Opposite the line are galleries of art such as Gallery Hyundai, Kumho Museum, Hakgojae, and Kukje Gallery. Gallery Hyundai is a neighborhood that has occupied an axis of Korean art for a long time since it was relocated in 1975. That is why it is not just the entrance to Samcheong-dong, but also called Sagan-dong Gallery.
Art Museum and Beetle Tree
Here, a bold art space has entered. This is the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul, which opened in November 2013. After the Gwacheon Hall and Deoksugung Hall, it is the third National Museum of Contemporary Art. The Seoul Pavilion was controversial even before the decision was made on the current site. After the decision was made, it was considered an easy challenge. This is because of the historicity of the location. First of all, Gyeongbokgung Palace was located with one road in between. The old father, who was in the Jeongdok Library, was also restored, and the former ROK Armed Forces Command, which was built in the early 20th century, was also Registered Cultural Property No. 375. The environment of Samcheong-dong, Sogyeok-dong, and Sagan-dong, which are the entrances to Bukchon, and the existing village circulation were also considered. It was initially impossible to become a landmark in Seoul by vertically rising due to various regulations.
Red brick old knight building from Gangui-dong
Architect Hyun-Jun Min, who was in charge of the construction of the Seoul Pavilion, solved it as an archipelago that seems to have several islands, large and small. Seven buildings are grouped like an island, forming a whole called Seoul Hall. A public square was created between the building and the building to increase publicity. We aimed for an open art museum without walls.
The road to Jongchinbu
Like a wave flowing through the island, it passes through a square on a road and enters into an art museum or walks through the outer space just like walking through a park. Although it is an art museum, it is a park, a square, and a road. In the meantime, the buildings that differed in time reveal the historicity of Seoul as they travel to large and small islands of different ages. In addition, because of its low buildings, it has a unique landscape around Inwangsan. It is a magical run and wandering.
Young raindrop tree in the lecture hall of terracotta tile exterior
It is because of these characteristics that the Seoul Pavilion was well received. We have diversified the points of contact between ordinary visitors and potential visitors, Seoul citizens. Most of all, it breaks the preconception that modern art is difficult because the museum does not set itself up.
The entrance to Sogyeok-dong next to Gangui-dong
Alley in the art museum
The first impression was an old Kimusa temple built in the early 20th century. It is a space that serves as both the exhibition hall and the office building of the Seoul Hall. In 1928, it opened as an outpatient clinic of the affiliated clinic of Gyeongseong Medical College and expanded in 1932 ~ 3. It is the first basement level and the third basement level. After independence, it was used as the second affiliated hospital of the Seoul Medical University and the Army Integrated Hospital. It is also an important structure for architects because it is decorated with bricks in a reinforced concrete frame. The old Kimusa building was transformed as part of the Seoul Pavilion. The white paint was peeled off to restore red bricks at the time of completion. This is a new building for those with old memories, but it is still in its original form.
The center of the art center and the front court
After entering the entrance, head straight for the ticket office. For the first visit, we recommend that you go through the entrance to the Gimusa Temple and enter the art gallery yard. It's between the old Kimusa building and the Gangui-dong building. Prior to the yard, attention is focused on the open yard in front of Gangui-dong. Three birch trees stretched out toward Gyeongbokgung Palace. Wisteria tree is an evergreen tree planted in the royal courtyard. Young shadows on the glass of Gangui-dong attract attention. Not surprisingly, these trees, which were 170 years old, have been there even before the entrance of the Seoul Pavilion and the Knights. From the late Joseon Dynasty, we watched the upheaval of modern history with two eyes. Before the Seoul Pavilion, he is a witness and the history of the land. These are the trees that have been treated the most. It is possible to know the reason for standing and receiving special treatment like Jang Seung.
The work of the uncle and Kim Seung-young <Warm Chair>
Standing in the back of the rain tree, Gangui-dong is decorated with terracotta tiles. The light brown tile seems to be solid, but it has four colors. The calm and unflinching color scheme harmonizes with the characteristics of other buildings that make up the museum. You can go straight to the art gallery yard, but pass down the river, and head towards Jongchinbu. The left side of the aisle is an underground exhibition yard with a high wall but not visible. As an outdoor space on the basement floor, it helps natural light on the ground to seep into the underground exhibition hall. However, another meaning of the road is the fact that it is a village's transit route.
The view of Inwangsan beyond the art museum as seen from the bell
Across the road, it crosses the residential area to the east of the museum. Considered to be able to come and go freely even after the museum's operating hours are over. It is a neighborhood alley in the museum. It is the moment when the openness of the Seoul Hall shines once again. The close-up father looks at the edge of the museum's alley like a big adult.
You can see Seo Do-ho's work on display at the Seoul Box.
An art museum that embraces the city's time and nature
Jongchinbu, Seoul's tangible cultural property No. 9, was the institution that kept the genealogy and portraits of the king and took care of the royal family's work. The area around Jongchinbu was a place where Saganwon and Gyujanggak were located, and its significance was special. The Seoul Pavilion entered and restored what was moved to the Jeongdok Library while the knight was in charge. Even if it was built around the father's father, the Seoul Pavilion forms the center of the art museum, not an exaggeration. When I turn to meet the eyes of my father's widow, I realize that. It is a lawn that corresponds to the roof of the 5th exhibition hall of the museum, and it moves as if taken in the landscape.
Shin Hyun Joong's Republican Guard
Between the red bricks of the old Kimusa temple and the terracotta exterior of Gangui-dong, the walls of Gyeongbokgung Palace and the mountains of Inwangsan were like ink. Past and present, city and nature blend in one frame. It is clear that the lower my body, the more I can bear more. At your feet, you can see people going across the yard of the museum. It also reveals how the old brick wall and the newly built art gallery meet. You don't have to stand up and see. On the lawn, Seungyoung Kim's work, <Warm Chair>, responds to visitors. It is a red boiler-type chair, 36.5 degrees, equal to a person's body temperature. If you sit on top of it and warm up, the warmth reaches your heart.
A view of Exhibition Hall 1, where natural light shines through the entire exhibition hall
The interior of the museum's interior exhibition hall is no different from the exterior. Rather than being stiff, we respect the choices of visitors. Architect Hyun-Jun Min compares with Rotonda at the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, designed by Frank Gary. If the Guggenheim Museum defines the circulation in advance, the Seoul Museum is free to open the circulation of visitors. The main advantage is that as the main buildings are floating like an archipelago, the eight exhibition halls inside can be explored as if exploring space. It does not lead directly to the exhibition hall from the lobby. In the east, the works of Seoul Box show up slightly. Beyond that, the horizontal window shows a slight trace of his father-in-law. The other side is the red brick of the Kimusa building. If you pass underneath and go to the left, it is the entrance to the art museum coming from Gimusa. In the aisle was a museum shop. This also breaks the framework of the Jongrye, which is located at the end of the museum's Dongseon.
Seo Do-ho's large-scale work 'Hanjin Shipping Box Project'
Freely beyond space and boundaries
The exhibition begins by entering the entrance on the first floor. Writer Shin Hyun-joong's Republican Guard stands slightly in front. It is an interesting piece that resembles a salamander. The first exhibition hall is on the right and the stairs to the rear are the eighth exhibition hall on the second floor. The first exhibition room controls the amount of natural light because it is a screen ceiling. Natural light that illuminates the entire space relieves viewers of fatigue. When you go down the escalator, you can see the 7th exhibition hall from the 2nd exhibition hall centered on the Seoul box. Meanwhile, there are media labs and movie theaters. The north is an exhibition yard under the left wall of the road to Jongchinbu and an exhibition space leading to the ground floor.
Writer Wooram Choi's <Opertus Lunula Umbar>
If you go down to the first basement level, you will first encounter the Seoul box. It is the most interesting exhibition hall. It is a space of light without diffused light coming in and without shadow. It is an exhibition space that reaches 17m in height and is currently underway by Seo Do-ho's <Hanjin Shipping Box Project>. <House in House, House in House, House in House> made of blue polyester fabric creates a hanok in a house floating in the air inside a western-style house. In the central hall going from the Seoul box to the multi-project hall, Choi U-ram's on-site production installation project <Opertus Lunula Umbra (Hidden Shadow of the Moon)> was caught in the air. Works resembling a crescent moon or a caterpillar move as if spreading their wings as if breathing at regular intervals. On the ceiling where the work was installed, colored panels of Saekdong were attached. It is the only decoration in the interior where there is only a partition and a movement line without much decoration. In the surroundings, artworks full of individuality await in each exhibition room. You don't have to go back in order. It's best to watch the fish freely as you walk, as if swimming in the sea. So is the designer's intention. Edwin van der Heider's installation work <Evolutionary Spark Network>, which fills a 15m-wide and 12m-long space, and Philip Bisley's <Vegetation Botanical Garden> collaborated by architects, engineers, and designers are more interesting when they come across like a coincidence. .
Outdoor exhibition yard on the first basement level
After the exhibition, it is time to go outside and hang around the museum. We even enjoy the beauty of the space that has been missed. The harmony created by meeting and breaking up with the surrounding space is another pleasure to greet the Seoul Hall. Then, you can move back to Gyeongbok Palace, Samcheong-dong, Sogyeok-dong, or Bukchon Hanok Village. The National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul has the island as its concept, but it is one of the countless islands. It meets the surrounding spaces and forms and completes a perfect entity. It is for this reason that it has a history of Seoul that is disgusting in its arms.
<Zite Geist-Spirit of Spirit> Exhibition held at the opening exhibition
Travel information

National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul
Address: 30 Samcheong-ro, Jongno-gu, Seoul
Opening hours: 10 am to 6 pm (until 8 pm on Wednesdays and Saturdays), closed on January 1 and every Monday
Admission Fee: Seoul Hall integrated ticket 7,000 won, Seoul Hall-Gwacheon Hall integrated ticket 10,000 won, Gygaist-era spirit (including field production installation project) 3,000 won, consolidation-deployment (including field production installation project) 7,000 won, Aleph project (Including field production installation project) 5,000 won
Contact: 02-3701-9500

www.mmca.go.kr

1.Access

* Self-driving

Sejong-daero → Turn right at Gwanghwamun Intersection → Turn left at Gyeongbokgung Intersection → National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, Seoul

* public transport

Take Exit 1 of Anguk Station on Subway Line 3 and turn right at Gyeongbokgung Station Intersection (Dongsipakgak) and walk about 300m (about 15 minutes on foot). Alternatively, take Exit 2 of Gwanghwamun Station on Subway Line 5, turn right in front of Gwanghwamun, and then turn left at the first Gyeongbokgung Station intersection (Dongsipakgak) (about 17 minutes on foot).


2. Restaurants around

item.title: Butterflies, cold forests in the sight of animals ~ Seoul forest in midwinter - Seongdong-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Seoul Forest Butterfly Ecological Garden

Butterflies, cold forests in the sight of animals ~ Seoul forest in midwinter

Seongdong-gu, Seoul, Korea

Winter cannot be crouched like a pupa in the room. Children's winter vacation has also started, and it is time for a full-fledged play program. When the cold wind blows, it goes to Seoul Forest. The Seoul Forest, which stands for the ecological forest in the city center, is not only the possession of gorgeous green and foliage. When you arrive through the cold, you will encounter a gentle and lively sight. In Seoul Forest, you can meet colorful butterflies, novel insects, and animals even in the middle of winter.

“Is it really cold, but do butterflies fly?”
“Then, you can still see butterflies in winter.”
The conversation between the mother and the child is interesting. Butterfly watching in the cold season is a strange reversal. There's another fun thing about smelting or mullet fishing through the ice.
A space exhibiting specimens of butterflies
In winter, the Seoul forest is thin. Although the river breeze blows from the Han River, the open forest does not stop the bitter wind. Butterflies meet in a warm space with their hands tightly frozen.
Insect plant

In Seoul Forest, the space where you can see butterflies is an insect botanical garden. Butterflies flying in the warm season of the butterfly garden move their nests to the interior of the 2nd floor of the Insect Botanical Garden. When you enter the Butterfly Eco Museum, which is open for free, you can meet the wings of swallowtail butterflies, wild swallowtail butterflies, and yellow butterflies. Butterflies become somewhat sluggish when the weather gets cold. Between 11 am and 2 pm during the day, a good sunshine time is when the butterfly is most active.

Botanical garden walkway
From pupa to butterfly, butterfly ecology
Even if Dongjang-gun tries to ride, it is another spring in Butterfly Ecological Garden. The flowers are in full bloom and the temperature is quite high. If you're wearing a thick coat, sweat is on your forehead. If you look closely, you can observe the butterflies flying on the ceiling or the wall in the corner, in addition to the butterflies flying on the flowers. The process of hanging a rope on a board like a tightrope and turning a pupa into a butterfly is also revealed.
“It's ugly now, but if you take off the pupa as if you wake up from a hibernation, it will become a colorful butterfly.”
If the biological common sense that was usually told to the child is reproduced as it is in front of the eyes, understanding grows in one word. At the Butterfly Ecology Center, various events are held for Christmas lovers, such as flying butterflies and giving a butterfly sample event.
Insect Botanical Garden Insect Exhibition
Even if you go outside the ecological hall, there are plenty of interesting things to see. There is a separate butterfly exhibition hall where you can observe rare butterflies from all over the world, so you can learn the ecology of butterflies. In addition to butterflies, more than 100 species of insects inhabit the Insect Botanical Garden. You will encounter rare insects such as stag beetles, longevity scarabs, and double star crickets and giant spiders that you have only seen in books.
The process of transformation from pupae to butterfly
It is not easy to escape the warm insect garden. Watching interesting animals, such as turtles, salamanders, and tapeworms, hiding amongst tropical plants, you will forget about the winter cold for a while.
turtle
Winter forest filled with cute fun

After walking out of the Insect Botanical Garden, we walk to the promenade with flower deer. Seoul Forest provides outdoor spaces where you can meet cute animals even in winter. In the 'House of Small Animals' next to the observation deck, you can see the cute and busy appearance of the guinea pigs. The experience of feeding deer directly from the deer cage is also fresh. There is a time to buy food at the field and feed the deer directly in the snow field. You will experience the fact that Seoul Forest is an ecological space where wild animals such as deer, elk and squirrel play. The experience of feeding deer with winter butterflies is an unforgettable memory for children.

guinea pig
Roads that cross Seoul Forest like a maze are also good for winter walks. Among the 30 experience spaces, giant statues, etc. are transformed into hide-and-seek and slide-riding spaces in winter. The lawn, where cars and bicycles do not go, is filled with laughter from children who make snowmen and fight snow.
Flower Deer Feeding Experience

First of all, it is necessary to recall the colorful modifiers attached to Seoul Forest.

“If you have Central Park in New York and Hyde Park in London, there is Seoul Forest in Seoul.”

Even near the place of life on a winter day, these informative and interesting experiences await. Seoul Forest is easily accessible by subway. After the Seoul Forest Station of the Bundang Line, it became possible to connect immediately without having to stay in the cold for a long time.

Seoul Forest Trail
Travel information

Seoul Forest
Address: 273 Ttukseom-ro, Seongdong-gu, Seoul
Contact: 02-460-2905

http://parks.seoul.go.kr/

1.Access

* Self-driving

* public transport

5 minutes from Seoul Forest Station on the Bundang Line and 15 minutes from Ttukseom Station on Line 2

2. Restaurants around

item.title: The place that became the background of Hong Sang-soo's movie “Bukchon direction”! Seoul Bukchon - Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Hanok Alley at 31, Gahoe-dong, which has become a landmark of Bukchon

The place that became the background of Hong Sang-soo's movie “Bukchon direction”! Seoul Bukchon

Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea

There is no need to hesitate to go to Bukchon even on a sunny day. Going out on a cloudy or snowy day goes well. At least, after watching Hong Sang-soo's movie <Bukchon Direction>. In black and white, Bukchon captures the daily and winter memories of 'movie fighters'. <Bukchon direction> is <Oh! Sujeong> Since then, it is Hong Sang-soo's second black-and-white film, which also advances to the Cannes Film Festival.

In fact, Bukchon's popularity has skyrocketed these days. Even in the middle of winter, people who come and go in the hanok alley are still walking. It has become a regular course for tourists from Japan and China to visit when visiting Seoul.
"I'm sorry, but there are Chinese and Japanese guides, but there is no Korean version." The clothes of the guide helper on the alley in Bukchon are pink. It stands out from a distance, but for a moment, I think for a moment that it doesn't go well with a scene in a movie or Hanok.
In <Bukchon direction>, Yoo Joon-sang (Seongjun station), Kim Sang-jung (Yeongho station), and Song Seon-mi (Boram station) are former film directors, film critics, and professors. Yoo Joon-sang, who played the lead role, seems to be about Hong Sang-soo's self-portrait.
Alleys and regular restaurants featured in the movie
A trip to Bukchon in harmony with <Bukchon direction> may start from the intersection of Anguk Station, or start with a car at Jeongdok Library. Both are places where the film was set. In front of the Jeongdok Library, they had a chat by drinking coffee written by Joon-sang Yoo and Sang-joong Kim, and Gilmok between Anguk Station and the Constitutional Court appeared as usual with drunken soldiers in the movie. When it comes to repeating places, you can't miss the Korean restaurant 'Dajeong' and the bar and cafe 'Novel'. The actual atmosphere is similar to the movie scene.
Jeongdok Library as the Background in the Movie
"It's not that the filmmakers come often. Hong Sang-su is the regular here. I also filmed the next movie with Mr. Ja-ok Kim."
In the words of Hanjeongsik's aunt, it seems that you can see 'Dajeong', which the main characters have enjoyed in Hong's next film. On the back wall of 'Dajeong', there is a large poster attached to the place where <Bukchon direction> was filmed. The herbs, Bossam, and Haejangguk are delicious. The directors say that they will never eat anything that tastes bad, no matter how much they eat it.
<Bukchon direction> Poster and Korean restaurant 'Dajeong'
The movie <Bukchon Direction> is interesting because it does not contain the common sights of Bukchon. If the Bukchon Cultural Center or Hanok Street was projected as a long take, the movie might have been a bit frustrating. On the screen, alleys, restaurants, and pubs that people come and go on a daily basis are simply mixed.
Puppet Museum
The cafe 'Novel' passed through Jaedong Elementary School and entered the back alley of the Myeongin Art Museum. It would not have been easy to find a space in a movie that had entered a dead end without a signboard with only the palm of the novel. As in the movie, the owner of the novel is temporarily absent. The place where Sung Joon (Jun Sang Yoo) played the piano, exchanged farms with the owner of the cafe, and fell in love is the 'novel'.
'Novel', a cafe where the protagonists' love has grown
A walk around Bukchon where the past and present are evenly mixed
The places that set the background for the film slowly fill the corners of Bukchon. As you walk, Bukchon's specialty comes out naturally. These days, the Bukchon walk is conducted with various themes. There are also good places to take a commemorative photo called 'Bukchon Eight Views'.
Gye-dong alley filled with residents' lives
The hanok alley in the 31st district of Gahoe-dong is the best preserved hanok in Bukchon. The Gye-dong alley from the modern office building to the Jungang High School contains the lives of old residents, such as old baths, clinics, and barber shops. In addition to this, Bukchon's main walking course is the Gahoe-dong workshop alley with open hanoks and workshops, the Sagan-dong gallery alley with galleries, and the school alley in front of Deokseong Girls' High School, where many restaurants are located. If you take a simple route called 'Bukchon Walk' before going on a walk in the alley, it will serve as a good guide.
Bukchon Hanok Interior
Bukchon alleys appear in Doseong-do, painted in 1750. In 2013, the lives of residents and Gentiles in Bukchon are also entangled.
Bukchon Hanok 'Rock Gojae'
The movie <Bukchon direction> ends like this. Seongjun, who was roaming Bukchon without a job, stumbles upon his fan (Hyunjeong Jung) to become a photo model. Behind the awkward-looking protagonist, an old alley map of Bukchon is captured by the camera side by side.
Placards at the beginning of the hanok alley
The season that sets the background for the movie is snowy winter. Watching the movie in the same season and going for a walk in Bukchon is quite worthy. In other words, you can feel the scent of Bukchon, which is different in color than before.
Bukchon Cultural Center where you can get a glimpse of the life of Bukchon

item.title: Secluded waterside in the middle of the city center, Suseong-dong Valley, Okin-dong, Seoul - Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Conceptual map of Suseongdong Valley

Secluded waterside in the middle of the city center, Suseong-dong Valley, Okin-dong, Seoul

Jongno-gu, Seoul, Korea

In the middle of Seoul, there is a secluded valley at the foot of Inwangsan. There are not many people, but there are those that support Inwangsan Mountain. Suseong-dong Valley, which also appeared in <Jangdong-pal Hinges> by Joong-jae Jeong, has come to us in a form almost identical to that of the Joseon Dynasty.
The valley of the Joseon Dynasty revealed in the place of the pilot apartment
The valley called Suseong-dong Valley became famous because of the loud valley water. It wasn't until July 2011 that we revealed the hidden image to us.
Suseong-dong Valley with Inwangsan in the background
The Suseongdong Valley was discovered in 2010 when the Okin Demonstration Apartment was demolished in 2010, and was restored to the park in recognition of its historical value. The park, located just above the end of the village bus in Okin-dong, Jongno-gu, is newly renovated and clean.
Giraffe in 'Jangdong Arm Hinges' by Joongjae Jeong Sun
From the Joseon Dynasty, this area was called Suseong-dong and was also introduced as a scenic spot. You can see the unchanging appearance of the Seongseong-dong Valley in Jeongseon Jeong's painting, Jangdong-pal Hinges.
A dazzling valley spreads under the Giraffe Bridge.
In particular, the fact that the Giraffe bridge, which is about 1.5m in length, placed at the beginning of the valley is almost similar to the painting of Gyeomjae, attracted attention. Giraffe is the only stone bridge preserved in its original form in the city, and it is interesting to note that it is made of stone.
Suseongdong Valley where butterflies come out
The cliff on which the Giraffe Bridge is situated is rather dangerous, and because of the fear of damaging the bridge, you can't cross the fence directly, but it's fun just by comparing it to the picture of Joongjae.
The promenade with Geumgyeuk
Across from the Giraffe Bridge, there is a sperm that is good for rest. When I sit in this pavilion, I can see Inwangsan in the future, and I have a valley next to it, so I feel like I have to stop by.
Cozy sperm in Suseongdong Valley
Aunts who live in the neighborhood come out with fruits and flirt on the mat, spending the middle of the summer at leisure.
The pavilion next to the valley is a shelter for residents
On a rainy day, come to the Suseongdong Valley
Chusa Kim Jeong-hee wrote the poem <Watching a Waterfall in the middle of Suseong-dong> against the backdrop of the Suseong-dong Valley. Because it is located in the middle of the city, it was a place where you could easily get along with nature without going anywhere. In addition to the outstanding scenery set in Mt.
Small but deep forest of Suseongdong Valley
However, the Suseongdong Valley has a fatal weakness. The point is that it is difficult to see the valley water normally. Even though it has been raining for several days, the waterway quickly disappears. So, you should go to the rainy day or the day after it rains so that you can enjoy the scenery of the Suseongdong Valley properly.
The Suseongdong Valley, where salamanders and crayfish live, is the birthplace of Cheonggyecheon.
At the top of the valley, pine trees, walnut trees, hawthorn trees, and arrow trees form a lush forest, exuding fresh energy. Since the mountain is not deep, you can see the cool stream only after it is raining in general, but if you look carefully, you can still find a place to soak your feet quietly. It is a secret waterside like a secret garden. It is said to be a salamander habitat, so it is hard to say how clear the water is. The promenade around Suseong-dong Valley is well maintained, and is used as a resting place for nearby residents.
Family dipping and playing in the Suseongdong Valley
The park surrounding the Suseongdong Valley is compact. In 10-15 minutes, you can take a round. It looks like a recently created park, but it is a pity because it feels somewhat artificial. Nevertheless, there are traces of the efforts to preserve the old appearance by exposing the rock of the valley as much as possible at the time of restoration. It is not a pleasure to be able to meet the valley of the Joseon Dynasty in the place where the old apartment disappeared. After all, forest is better than buildings, and nature is better than man-made.
Afternoon in the water, sky, trees and pavilion
Climb up to the top of the valley to meet the Skyway of Inwangsan. If you cross one of the main roads, you will be connected to the Inwangsan Trail, and if you walk along the Skyway, you will pass through one sperm and lead to Buam-dong's “Poet's Hill”. It is also a good idea to walk along the road to Seoul Castle.
The ecosystem of the Suseongdong Valley is still strong
Travel information

item.title: Enjoy the weather caster experience, and also weather forecast, Seoul Meteorological Agency - Dongjak-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Meteorological Agency outdoor observation

Enjoy the weather caster experience, and also weather forecast, Seoul Meteorological Agency

Dongjak-gu, Seoul, Korea

How is the weather in Korea this summer? Let's take a look at the three-month forecast from the Korea Meteorological Administration from June to August 2013. “The summer temperature will be higher than the average, and the precipitation will be similar to the average. 9 to 11 typhoons will occur, and 1 to 2 will affect Korea. ” If you look at this in detail by month, “There will be many cloudy days under the influence of low pressure in July and many hot days under August under the influence of high pressure in the North Pacific.” Families interested in weather forecasting and meteorological phenomena should visit the Korea Meteorological Administration and enjoy experiential learning. Like a weather forecaster, you can draw a weather map based on the air pressure layout and stand in front of a TV camera to become a weather caster that delivers weather news.

As soon as you enter the front door of the Japan Meteorological Agency, you can see the right and left sides. In 1441, during the time of King Sejong in Joseon, a rain gauge to measure rainfall was invented. Previously, it was said to measure the depth of rainwater that had penetrated the ground with a homina plow. The rain gauge displayed on the porch of the Korea Meteorological Administration is a reproduction of the gold rain gauge (treasure No. 561), which was produced in 1837 and used in Gongyeong Gamyeong (Geumyeong). The authentic product was taken out to the Japan Meteorological Agency during the Japanese colonial rule, and was returned in 1971. It is divided into three stages, and it is a bamboo ruler called ‘Jukcheok’.
The sideband refers to the side stand. There are two exhibits on the porch, one of which is the Gwanwoodae (Treasure No. 843), which was in a sense of contemplation. Gwansanggam is the government office in charge of astronomical, geographic, and posthumous affairs in the Joseon Dynasty.
Large pictures of Sejong's servants and their raindrops on the side of the raincoat and the raincoat catch the visitors' attention. The spirit of Sejong's love for the people seems to be transmitted vividly in the 21st century.

Sejong and Woowoogi Pictures

The Meteorological Agency experience learning is conducted in the order of watching the Meteorological Agency video, drawing a weather map, visiting observation equipment, experiencing weather casters, and exploring outdoor observation equipment. On the first day of each month, you can apply for experiential learning for the next month. Individual experiences are held every Wednesday, and group experiences are held every Thursday and Friday. Online reservations are only available through the Japan Meteorological Agency website. The duration of the experience is about 2 hours.
First, we gather in the auditorium to find out what the Korea Meteorological Administration is doing through animation. Cartoon protagonists tell the process of weather forecasting without boring. It is conducted in the order of current weather identification, data collection, analysis, forecasting, and notification. Of course, a detailed explanation of each process follows. Also, find out the meaning of the sign that appears in the weather map. The parents who accompanied the children also miss a word and focus on their mind.

Meteorological Agency Introduction Animation protagonists

The symbols in the weather map have their own meaning. It means the amount of clouds, the direction of the wind, the speed of the wind, the current weather, and air pressure. In the final stage of drawing the weather map, it is necessary to complete the shape of air pressure bones such as low pressure and high pressure.
I need to know common sense about air pressure. The force that the air surrounding the Earth presses down by gravity is called air pressure. It is Italian physicist Torricelli who expresses the pressure in numbers. He experimented with filling a 1m glass tube with one end clogged with mercury and standing upside down in a mercury container. At this time, it was determined that one mercury column corresponds to a height of about 760 mm. The unit of air pressure is hectopascal (hPa).

Explaining the symbols of the weather map to the experience

After watching the video for about an hour, the children try to draw a diary. In the old days, it was unpredictable to see rain or drought. So, when there was a severe drought, even the king went out and stayed in the sky. How is it today? In order to protect people's lives and property, the Korea Meteorological Administration provides all kinds of scientific equipment such as supercomputers and meteorological satellites to provide weather information, typhoon information, and weather information. Also, in order to support the people's life and industrial activities, they regularly give out local and weekly forecasts, long-term forecasts, and even mountain and airport weather.
Weather forecasting is to grasp the change of weather from the past to the present and use it to predict how the weather in the future will change. Observe air temperature, air pressure, wind, humidity, precipitation, and clouds in a variety of ways, including automatic weather observation equipment, satellites, radar, ships, and aircraft. It analyzes the data collected not only in Korea but also around the world and draws a weather map. Based on this weather map, experienced weather forecasters deliver comprehensive weather forecasts to the public.
Weather forecasting has a great impact on our lives, our environment, and our industry. If you have a rain forecast, you can pack an umbrella when you leave the house. When the weather forecast that the sun will be bright will come out, the car wash is full. At industrial sites, we listen very closely to weather forecasts. Depending on the weather forecast for the upcoming season, you will be making a lot of winter clothes, increasing the production of air conditioning appliances, or adjusting the production of ice cream.

Draw a diary

After drawing the weather map, we go around the 2nd and 3rd floors, meet various observation equipment, and look around the weather station on the 1st floor. A large Donggwoldo Island hangs outside the weather station. You may be wondering, 'Which Donggwol in the Meteorological Office?' It is a document that proves. It is a passage that shows how deeply interested the kings and servants of Joseon were in the weather.
Back in Hyundai, you too have time to become a weather caster. Even though it is not a broadcasting station, I enter the studio and stand in front of the TV camera. I'm a weather caster today! In the news, just as the weather caster forecasts the weather, the experienced customers can confidently deliver the weather of tomorrow by looking at the weather map.

Weather-related materials displayed in the hallway
Weather Station Inside
Donggwoldo Island outside the Weather Station

Finally, we move to an outdoor observation site packed with weather observation equipment. On one side of the lawn, rainwater, wind, and anbuil are gathered. The Punggidae here is a replica of the Punggidae of Changgyeonggung Palace and is a stand to build the punggi. The Punggidae was built in the main palaces and observatory until the early 18th century. Currently, there are Punggidae, Changgyeonggung Palace and Punggidae, Gyeongbokgung Palace. The wind direction was determined and the wind speed was judged by waving the flag.
The white white leaf image, which was thought to be the pronoun of the Korea Meteorological Administration, remains on the observation site. If you open the door and look inside, there is a high temperature thermometer, a low temperature thermometer, and an Asman ventilation and humidity system. However, we no longer forecast the weather through Baek Yeop-sang. A variety of weather information is collected with an automatic weather system built next to a white leaf.

White leaf statue of outdoor observer
Pollen observation equipment of outdoor observer
Travel information

[Meteorological Agency]
Address: 61, Yeouidaebang-ro 16-gil, Dongjak-gu, Seoul
Contact: 02-2181-0567, www.kma.go.kr

1.Access

* Self-driving

[When going from downtown] Daebang-ro Daebang Station Underpass → Daerim-dong → Boramae Park West Gate → Parking in Meteorological Agency in front of Dongjak Fire Station
[When going from outside the city] Siheung-daero → Enter Daebang-ro → Boramae Park Preface → Parking in Meteorological Agency in front of Dongjak Fire Station

* public transport

Take the village bus No. 05 (Dongjak) to the right of Exit 4 of Sindaebang Station on Subway Line 2 and get off at the final stop (Boramae Park Seomun)
15 minutes walk from Boramae Station Exit 2 of Subway Line 7 toward Boramae Park West Gate

2. Restaurants around

Thyme: Bull painting / 15 Boramae 5-gil, Dongjak-gu / 02-3284-1240 / www.63borame.co.kr

Steamed seafood rice cake 0410: Steamed seafood rice cake / 22 Noryangjin-ro 16-gil, Dongjak-gu / 02-824-0410 / http://www.sf0410.co.kr

Sangdo Galbi Town: Galbi / 13, Maebong-ro, Dongjak-gu / 02-816-5492 / www.kalbitown.co.kr

3.Accommodation

M2 Motel: 164 Sangdo-ro, Dongjak-gu / 02-822-5432
Kozaja Motel: 5, Sadang-ro 30-gil, Dongjak-gu / 02-582-5901

item.title: Jinhon and Yeomwon's House, Seoul War and Women's Human Rights Museum - Mapo-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
War and Women's Human Rights Museum

Jinhon and Yeomwon's House, Seoul War and Women's Human Rights Museum

Mapo-gu, Seoul, Korea

This museum is located in a residential area under Seongmi Mountain in Seongsan-dong, Mapo-gu. In 2012, he won the Grand Prize at the Seoul Architecture Awards. The museum records the painful history of the survivors of the Japanese comfort women. A building built with bricks is not overwhelmed by its scale and is not decorated with splendor.

8-year-old museum
Demand protests are held every Wednesday in front of the Japanese Embassy in Seoul. It is a place to urge the Japanese “comfort women” problem. Victims of the comfort women, members of the Korea Mental Problems Countermeasures Council (Jung Dae-hyup), citizens, and students participate. The protest, which began on January 8, 1992, reached its 1,000th on December 14, 2011. On that day, the Peace Monument (Girls' Award) was established. The girl statue wears a raincoat on rainy days and a shawl in winter. The War and Women's Human Rights Museum opened on May 5, 2012, the following year. The spirit of space is an extension of demand demonstrations. It contains a willingness to remember the painful history of comfort women survivors and to solve the problem. Going one step further, we aim for a world without war and violence against women.
The process of building the museum was not only smooth. In 1994, the Preparatory Committee for the Construction of Feed Museums was established. In 1999, a small educational center was established to inform the history of the Japanese comfort women near Seodaemun. It was in 2004 that discussions on building the museum took place in earnest. Chung Dae-hyup launched the War and Women Human Rights Museum Establishment Committee, and the government life support fund raised by 17 comfort women grandmothers became the cornerstone. Initially, it was planned to be built in Seodaemun Independence Park. However, in March 2009, the first shovel had to be stopped. Unexpectedly, the defamation of the Sunkuk Seonyeol was the reason for opposition. It wasn't until August 2011 that the site was purchased at the foot of Seongmi Mountain. The cost of construction was raised through donations and fundraising activities by citizens such as the “10,000 Won Donation Relay Campaign”. Japanese citizens also joined. It was a process that took 8 years to complete after the construction committee was established. Sometimes it is not easy to take for granted the fact that it is so natural.
The War and Women's Human Rights Museum is less than 1 km from Hongik University Station. It is a street corner of the residential area that entered the alley toward Seongmisan Mountain at the intersection of Gyeongseong High School. If you turn the wall of gray brown bricks, you will see the entrance. On the wall, there are letters written on yellow butterfly-shaped paper. It is the trace of citizens who visited the museum. A 23-year-old woman wrote, "I hope that this will never happen again." It is mostly about cheering up comfort women and pledge themselves. The yellow butterfly is a symbol of Jeong Dae-hyup's activities, meaning hope and solidarity. As I turned around the corner along the wings of a butterfly, the building beyond the wall was a bit clearer. The color of the dark exterior walls surrounding the whole is solemn. In the alley, it was the part that was covered by fences and trees. The brick house is a little more realistic.
Yellow butterfly-shaped cheering notes on the wall
A shuddering pace
The War and Women's Human Rights Museum is the work of Wise Architects Young-cheol Jang and Jeon Suk-hee. They received the Young Architect Award from the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in 2010. Participated in projects such as ABC Office, Y House, and Lee Sang-Ho. The Museum of War and Women's Human Rights won the Grand Prize at the Seoul Architecture Awards. Their architecture is not a game of scale. It is also characterized by developing various architectural and cultural activities together.
The museum has no historical connection with Seongmisan. This is a remodeling of a two-story house of about 344m2, which is the home of an ordinary person. The comfort women issue is a tremendous event that has shaken the lives of ordinary people. In that sense, the first impression of a dark gray-brown house and a house that sits at the end of a narrow alley makes the meaning reminiscent. It is a symbol of a space without a symbol.
Open the door and enter the room. Dark space, the beginning of the journey. Buy a ticket at the right side of the entrance. It is different from the existing admission ticket. By purchasing a ticket, you have a relationship with a woman who is a comfort woman. It is the process of going to see him, and through him, we look into the life of a comforting woman. First, we face the interaction video on the wall of the reception room. It is a butterfly that flies out of the frame. It is a wing that goes beyond the wall of violence and discrimination. The first step goes out there again. Rather than going straight into the exhibition room on the first floor, it is a movement that experiences an external space and goes up to the ground building through the basement.
Picture of a girl on the left wall of a crushed stone road
When you open the door to the outside, you can hear the boots. The crushed stone road now opens. The narrow passageway at the edge of the building leads to the basement. The road about 1m wide was laid with crushed stone and artificial gravel. On the left is a picture of a black girl, and on the right is an old man's face and hand relief. Visitors walk through the gaps of time in the meantime. It is a history of war madness and violence that they had to go through. The pebble echo spreads in a narrow space, knocking on the door of the heart A few steps by the comfort women were drawn by the stairs going down the ground after passing through the crushed stone path. This is also awesome.
Face and hand relief are the comfort women's present.
The underground exhibition hall reconstructed the comfort station with a yoke. It was originally used as a boiler room for a house. In the photo of the ticket received when entering, the grandmother interview is shown. This day is the testimony of Hong Kang-rim's grandmother. Born in Gimcheon, North Gyeongsang Province in 1922, he was taken to Bongcheon, China in 1938. She ended her life in China without stepping on her homeland. “I ca n’t go, I ca n’t come… . ” Following that lonely confession, she looks back on her life. In the middle of a cryptic underground room, hair shoes and shoes are placed neatly like a store.
Another room where the past and reality intersect
45,000 pieces All bricks with eager breeze
Head to the 2nd floor from the underground exhibition hall. It is a copper line that goes down from the basement to the first floor after going through the second floor. The walls of the landing are concrete bricks. It is a smooth, unbroken deadline like the remains of a ruins. The skeleton revealed when the walls were torn to remodel the house into a museum was left untouched. It feels like a long history of fighting for comfort women. In the meantime, pictures and bricks of comfort women were placed. The core in the chest remained a text for each brick. A bloody voice echoes along the stairs. Nevertheless, the more you climb the stairs, the more hopeful it is. I hope that the same pain will not be repeated to someone else. It is a wish in the name of the Museum of War and Women's Human Rights. Before facing the exhibition space on the second floor, a work called "Flowers Blooming in the Border" by artist Jun-Hwa Ryu took. He wanted women not to be seen as simple victims. Think briefly about the life that will bloom across the border.
Comfort woman grandmother's words engraved on the stairs brick
The exhibition room on the second floor is a little clearer. The ceiling on the first floor is open to the second floor. On the left and right, the list of donors remained as a donor wall. Around the perimeter, there are exhibition spaces, such as a history hall, a sports hall, and a life hall. The History Museum displays Japanese military documents and related materials. The first sentence is the term ‘comfort women’. It was written from the point of view of the perpetrated man, but it was written in quotation marks to reveal the historical concept. Beneath it was a comfort card and a condom named “Assault No. 1”, which was given to soldiers, and a diary describing the contents of the Japanese troops going to the comfort station. The exercise academy looks at the footsteps of efforts to resolve the comfort women problem. The scene of demand demonstrations that continue every Wednesday is also reproduced. The Peace Monument girl statue was also present. The Life Hall displays the remains of victims. Now go to the memorial hall connected to the balcony on the second floor.
Ryu Jun-hwa's <Flowers Blooming in the Border>
The memorial hall is a striking exterior of the museum when viewed from the outside. Bricks were piled up intentionally and carefully to allow light and wind to pass. For each brick, the faces, names, and date of death of the grandmothers who were victims of 170 women were recorded. Victims who failed to leave their names and faces are honored with black bricks. In the gap between the bricks, flowers of memorial were placed. Next to the entrance, there was a donation box. The donation will be used for the next visitor's wreath. Then he goes back to the first floor.
An athletic academy that reproduces the scene of demand demonstrations
The first floor is close to the exhibition hall. There is a permanent exhibition on the theme of world conflict and violence against women. A space for participation was also prepared. You can also go out to the museum front yard. In the yard, the exterior of the museum is clearer. A total of 45,000 bricks are piled up to form a complete body. It is the sum of some winds. Which brick to treat easily? Which death will pass easily? Even if you don't try to interpret it, the hidden meaning is clear.
History museum exhibiting Japanese military documents and materials
Eight years is an hour of hard work. It is a sincere and solidarity that has been piled up one by one with donations and donations. It is an earnest desire and a wish. Above all, it is a footprint of pain and suffering that cannot be expressed in words. It is a message of architecture that is revealed at once.
Memorial flowers in the crevices
Travel information

War and Women's Human Rights Museum
Address: 20 World Cup Buk-ro 11-gil, Mapo-gu, Seoul
Contact: 02-365-4016

www.womenandwar.net

1.Nearby Restaurants

2.Accommodation

http://www.hotelseokyo.co.kr/asp/view/main/main.asp

item.title: Alleys of memories with art - Seongbuk-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
Poetry of Poet Kim Gwang-gyun in Daehak-ro
Samsa building

Alleys of memories with art

Seongbuk-gu, Seoul, Korea

From the Daehak-ro, the street of culture, the path to Seongbuk-dong, where Han Yong-woon's deep actors and novelist Sang-tae Lee and Tae-jun Lee's Suyeonsanbang go beyond Naksan, is an alley to memories with poetry, novels and murals.

Poetry meets mural

Exit Hyehwa Station Exit 2 and look back to see the Samsa building covered in ivy leaves. The starting point of this walking tour is the building, but before we start, we look back at the fertilization on the street.
The poet Kim Gwang-gyun's poetry, who wrote the poem <Snowy Night,> begins with "Where's the good news / because it's noisy?" In front of the tombstone engraved with <Seolha>, we examine the poet's delicate feelings of a season.

Come back to Samsa Temple, back on the main road, go straight to the road next to Samsa Temple, turn right at Samgeori, go a little, turn left, and then turn right at the next crossroad to follow the road. This is the way from Daehak-ro to Naksan Park. You can follow the milestones of Naksan Park or Seoul Castle.
As you go uphill, you will see the first mural. Wall paintings are called murals, but murals are like folk paintings that have been passed down since ancient times. The Korean National Encyclopedia defines “People painting as a popular commercialization made according to the traditional customs of a nation or individual,” so it is natural that a camel pictured on the wall of the village was named because it resembled a camel. It will be work.
Road with camel pictures
It was not difficult to think of childhood at the wall of an old house. Sunny alleys have always been the playgrounds of children in the neighborhood. When I heard the voices of the mothers calling the children, “Eat, eat” in the alley where the tide descended and ran until the darkness settled down, there was an evening returning home, trying hard to play more. When the lights on the dark alley windows turned on one by one, the moon floated on the back of the mountain, and it lit up the son-in-law.
Alleyway giraffe illustration
Fairy-tale paintings filled with walls
A small sculpture walking in the air came to my eyes while thinking of the old days. This is a scene of a man and a dog in suits stepping towards Naksan Forest and buildings in downtown Seoul. People passing by take pictures there. It seems that the forest, the city, and the village became the background of the cartoon film with one of the sculptures. It seems to have taken off the middle film of a story and brought it there. The beginning and end of the story will be different for each person looking at the sculpture.
People and dog sculptures
Old town under the castle
Leave the sculpture behind, follow the road, turn left and pass in front of Dongsung Daycare Center. Then, at the forked road, turn right. On the way, go up the stairs to the right, turn right, and go a little further to Naksanjeong. Before going to the sperm, 'Hongdeok Ibat' comes out.
Hongdeok Ibat is the place where the story of Bongrimdae and Hongdeok, who were taken hostage in the Qing Dynasty after the Byeongjahoran, remain. Hong Deok-yi put kimchi in a bowl at Bolmoji for the Bongrim troops who were captured. The Bongrim Daegun, who could not forget the taste, gave a field to eat the kimchi that Hong Deok-i soaked when he returned to Korea. After that, Hong Deok-yi grew cabbage in a field, and told Kim Bong-rim that became King Hyo-jong, soaked kimchi.
After passing the field of Hongdeok, take a sigh at Naksanjeong and go again. When the road with the castle comes out, turn left and go to Naksan Park. You can see the sign “Naksan Park” outside the castle wall. Move your steps to the lower village of Naksan Park.
Hongdeok-ibat, where the story of Bongrim-gun and one nine
Ipop tree
The way to Naksanjeong
The lower village of Naksan Park is Samseon-dong, just below Seoul Castle. This is the moon village where houses are built on a rock and houses of pottery are gathered in a narrow alley. In the alleys of Daldongne, like a spider web, two people who come across each other can barely pass by, but the scent of a rich life is evident in alleys.
Naksan Park
Naksan Park Ammun
Houses are gathered on the hillside, and the roof of the front house is under the wall of the upper house, and some houses have a courtyard. The owner of the slate roof, who grows a variety of flowers, will be a good person. Alleyways with cluttered wires The sky looks closer than you see in other houses beneath the mountain. A mother-cat is sitting on the roof without an eye on the human.
Naksan Park Alleyway Mural and Flowers
Naksan Park's Lower Village House with Various Flowers
House under the rock
Time passed by looking around the alleys of Dal-dong. Physical time also seems to have a different flow rate for each person. The sun has a way to go, but the alleys are warm with memories.
When you come down from the village, leave the Seoul Castle on the left and walk along the road just below the castle. The road leads to the subway station of Hanseong University.
Mural painting in the alleys of the lower village of Naksan Park
After entering Exit 4 of Hanseong University Station, exit 5 and follow the sidewalk to Hyehwamun. Hyehwamun is one of the eight gates that were built during the construction of the Seoul Castle in the early Joseon Dynasty. The door is open daily from 9 am to 6 pm. Enter the door, climb the stairs and follow the alley-like path. Then, go down the stairs and go out the door, and the castle continues across the street. Now walk the alleyways with the castle on the left. Along the way, if you continue to pass the Gyeongsin Middle and High School, you will see a wide driveway. Cross the crossing, turn right, and then go down a little and you will see the way to Seoul Castle.
After entering Exit 4 of Hanseong University Station, exit 5 and follow the sidewalk to Hyehwamun. Hyehwamun is one of the eight gates that were built during the construction of the Seoul Castle in the early Joseon Dynasty. The door is open daily from 9 am to 6 pm. Enter the door, climb the stairs and follow the alley-like path. Then, go down the stairs and go out the door, and the castle continues across the street. Now walk the alleyways with the castle on the left. Along the way, if you continue to pass the Gyeongsin Middle and High School, you will see a wide driveway. Cross the crossing, turn right, and then go down a little and you will see the way to Seoul Castle.
The left side of the picture is the lower village of Naksan Park.
Seoul Castle
The path I want to walk right next to Seoul Castle
If you go up the tree, you can see the three-way playground and go to the right path. When the stairs come out, don't go up there, but go out to the Ammun on the right side of the stairs.
Flowers bloom and alleyways are bright
Seongbuk-dong Seoul Castle Road
Simwoojang and Suyeonsanbang
When you leave Ammun, a completely different landscape unfolds. Seongbuk-dong Dal-dong's houses gathered and formed nests. When you go down the alley, you will see a driveway, and after going up a little, turn right at the intersection.
A bird painted on the wall of a house on the corner of the street catches the eye. It looks like a blue bird. A blue bird conveying hope, and several bird pictures can be seen on either side of the road. Someone who painted this painting probably wanted to draw hope in this town.
Seongbuk-dong Daldongne
After climbing the blue bird picture that conveys hope, the village parking lot is on the right side of the road, and you can see a telephone pole with a recycling bin. Put the telephone pole down the stairs to the right and enter the alley. Turn right at the three-way alley and turn right again at the next intersection.
Many birds appear in the murals of Daldongne in Seongbuk-dong
Seongbuk-dong Daldongne Mural Painting
Seongbuk-dong Daldongne is under Seoul Castle
Shim Woo-jang is the home of the independence activist and poet Man Yong Han Yong-woon who reached the end of his life. I didn't want to sit down in the direction of the Chosun Governor, so I built it in the north. A juniper tree that was planted at the time stands on one side of the yard, and the green pine needles cover the roof of the Simwoojang. There is also a manuscript containing his handwriting along with the portrait of Manhae in the Simwoojang.
Yongwoon Han's room
Manhae Han Yongwoon's Simwoojang
When you leave the deep right turn and turn left and go down the alley, you will see “Manhae's Walking Park” with the statue of Manhae. From there, turn right and follow the road to the Seongbuk Museum of Art across the street and the Hanok House next to it. The hanok is the home of the novelist Sang-he Lee Tae-jun. Now they are selling tea and drinks under the name 'Suyeonsanbang'.
Manhae's walking park with statue of Han Yong-woon
Sangheo Lee Tae-jun is a North Korean writer, and he and his work have not been introduced in Korea until the work was lifted in 1988. There are many short stories and feature stories such as <Moon Night>, <Oh Mong-Nyeo>, <Raining Rainy>, <Bokdeokbang>, <Youngwol Inspiration>, <Bamgil>. The house in Pocheon (Cheorwon) where he lived was moved to the present location, but the Sangsimru was burned down during the Korean War. The building in front of the booth is the seat of Sangsimru.
Sanghe Lee Taejun's house
The day of walking from Hakhak-ro to Seongbuk-dong, feeling the scent of art left on the alleys of memories, ends in Suyeonsanbang. There seems to be no good place like this to finish the day trip while enjoying the charm of Hanok.
Well in one side of Suyeonsanbang courtyard
Travel information

1.Access

Exit 2 of Hyehwa Station → Mural camel → People and dog sculptures → Naksanjeong → Naksan Park (Seoul Castle) → Naksan Park Alley Road in Seoul → Hanseong University Station along Seoul Castle Road → Hyehwamun → Gyeongsin Middle and High School → Seongbuk-dong Seoul Castle Road → Seongbuk-dong → Simwoojang → Suyeonsanbang

2. Restaurants around

Seongbuk-dong Pork Ribs Restaurant: Pork Ribs / 115 Seongbuk-ro, Seongbuk-gu / 02-764-2420

Seongbuk Seolleongtang: Seolleongtang / 266-4 Seongbuk 2-dong, Seongbuk-gu / 02-762-3342
Seongbuk Dongjip: Kalguksu, Mandu / 144 Seongbuk-ro, Seongbuk-gu / 02-747-6234

3.Accommodation

Stay in GAM Hostel: 12 Yulgok-ro 10-gil, Jongno-gu / 02-764-2052 / www.stayingam.com

Bukchon Inn: 99 Gyedong-gil, Jongno-gu / 070-4150-3428 / www.bukchoninn.com

Haemil Guest House: 15-14 Yulgok-ro 10-gil, Jongno-gu / 070-4195-7131 / www.haemilguesthouse.com

item.title: Yeouido 1st, Elementary Tour 1st National Assembly & Constitutional Memorial Hall - Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul, Korea
item.description:
View of the main assembly hall of the National Assembly Building

Yeouido 1st, Elementary Tour 1st National Assembly & Constitutional Memorial Hall

Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul, Korea

It is the 'President of Minui', but it is the place where the ordinary people cannot easily access. However, it is easy for anyone to visit and visit here if they want. However, if you make a reservation 3 days before the tour. A place that will be a good experience for adults as well as children's performance evaluation. In addition, it is closely related to the contents of the textbook, so in many ways it is worth calling it “the number one elementary field trip”.

Tours of the National Assembly are divided into the Constitutional Memorial Hall (the National Visitors Center) and the National Assembly. Previously, it was separate, but now it is possible to watch “one stop”. The Constitution Memorial Hall, which displays materials and artifacts related to the National Assembly of the Republic of Korea, can be freely visited, and the National Assembly Building must be gathered as a group at the time of reservation for guidance.
The dedication memorial hall is composed of the ‘Minister of the National Assembly’, ‘Temporary Assemblyman ’s Hall’, and ‘National Assembly Tour’. At the 'Temporary Court House', you can see the materials related to the provisional court and the first constitutional assembly, which is the legislative institution of the Korean Provisional Government. Space.
Upon receiving the guidance of the National Assembly guide, the House of Parliament listens to explanations of what the National Assembly is doing, and actually visits the main venue where the bill is being processed. The advantage is that all explanations are made to fit the eye level of the children. Rather than letting parents know something more by studying separately, it's a good idea to research the National Assembly with your child in advance and summarize your child's questions and ask the guide.

Then, let's go on a full-fledged tour of the National Assembly from now on. First, when you enter the entrance of the National Assembly, two Haitai greets visitors. Originally, Haitai is a legendary animal that judges fertility and good and evil. Because of this symbolism, it was a symbol of Saheungbu, an organization that inspects officials in the Joseon Dynasty. Perhaps the National Assembly stood in front of the National Assembly in the sense that the National Assembly would act on behalf of the people to monitor the government and correct the errors. Let's tell the children that this is the meaning of the name of the cookie maker.
Haitai Statue at the entrance of the National Assembly Building
Facing Haetaesang and walking to the right for about 5 minutes, today's first destination, the dedication memorial, appears. You can enter by entering the National Assembly Visitor Center on the right side of the entrance and confirming the reservation. When you open the three glass doors, you can see the portraits of the former National Assembly Speakers to the right of the large hall. The main hall is always in a 'special exhibition', but it is good to start watching by watching a promotional video about the functions and roles of the National Assembly right in the public relations video theater on the right. Robot Taekwon V comes out and kindly explains it to the eye level of children. If your father tells you that rumors of a robot Taekwon V secret base in the Capitol were spinning when he was a child, how would the children react?
Dedicated Memorial Lobby
If you go across the re-emerged central hall, you are the Minister of National Assembly. One thing you shouldn't miss here is to take a cyber authentication shot against the backdrop of various parliaments. The history and activities of the former National Assembly Speakers and the variety of souvenirs they have received from overseas are bonuses.
Minister of Parliament
The provisional courthouse, which is naturally connected to the Minister of National Assembly, is a place where you can see the process and activities of the provisional courthouse, which was the National Assembly of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea. If the Government of the Republic of Korea took over the provisional law of the Provisional Government, it can be said that the National Assembly was the authenticity of the Provisional Court. Another advantage is that you can see the activities of the temporary courtroom through panoramic images as well as photos and records.
Exhibition of the National Assembly
Next is the “President's Office produced by the Parliament,” which literally introduces the activities and achievements of the President of the National Assembly. Don't forget to take a commemorative photo here in a space that reproduces the president's office. Nowadays, children whose dreams are presidents will be rare, but when they were young, they told them that most children's dreams were presidents.
Temporary Court House
President's Office produced by Congress
The children's experience room, decorated with colorful primary colors, is a place where children can have fun. You can experience the functions of the Korean National Assembly and the principles of democracy while touching, turning, watching and enjoying. There is also a corner in the subsequent National Assembly of the Republic of Korea that informs the operation principle and composition of the Korean National Assembly and at the same time looks around the world's parliament. It would be interesting to compare our parliament with other parliaments. Looking at the Constitution Hall, the last exhibition room of the Memorial Hall, the supplementary explanation of the father is necessary. It explains what the Constituent Assembly is, and why it was necessary to convene from the Constitutional Assembly to establish a country after liberation.
Constitutional Council Miniature
“The Constituent Assembly is a parliament gathered to make a constitution. In order to establish a modern democratic country, we must first have a constitution. So, it was called from the Constituent Assembly before the establishment of the Korean government. Here is the day when the first constitution of the Republic of Korea is released. ” Isn't this enough?
Children's Experience Hall
It takes about an hour to tour all of the Memorial Halls. Then, in front of the Memorial Hall, take a shuttle bus to the National Assembly to head to the National Assembly Building. Unfortunately, the red carpeted staircase, which appears in the news every day, is an exclusive entrance to the National Assembly. Visitors must enter the parliament building by the back aisle. From here, the guide of the National Assembly staff begins.
National Assembly Visitor Shuttle Bus
The first stop is the National Assembly Hall. It is a space under the dome that looks like a symbol of the National Assembly Building. The marble on the floor and the lighting on the ceiling dome create an exotic atmosphere. After walking around the main hall for a while, we move to the 4th floor exhibition hall to hear brief explanations and see various activities of the National Assembly. This is a review of what I have already seen from the Constitutional Memorial Hall. The dedication memorial hall summarized the contents that were divided into various exhibition halls into a panorama on one wall. After looking around the exhibition hall, we will finally head to the highlight of today, the main assembly hall.
Inside the Capitol dome
The first impression I see in real life on a daily meeting of the main assembly hall on TV is 'it's less than I thought'. It is a phenomenon that many people use wide-angle lenses when trying to show the entire conference hall. While sitting on the second floor of the auditorium, looking at the main conference hall, we hear a full explanation of the functions and roles of the National Assembly.
National Assembly Main Building 4F Exhibition Hall
The most important thing that 299 members of Congress do in the National Assembly is legislative action that makes the law. People's lives are determined by what laws the National Assembly makes, so it is a very powerful authority. Next, the enactment activities to deliberate and inspect the country's livelihood. It is about deliberating and deciding on a country's budget for the year. In addition, the National Assembly is responsible for checking the administration. All these things are called ‘politics’. So politics is so important and essential that we can ignore it as dirty. This is why children should look around at the National Assembly and pay attention to politics.
First Parliament House

Constitutional Memorial Hall and the National Assembly Building are not the only highlights of the National Assembly. Along with the National Library of Korea, the National Library of Korea, the representative library in Korea, is also a place to go with children. In order to go with your child, you can visit the Internet three days before the desired date of visit. www.nanet.go.kr ) Must be applied in advance. If the weather is good, it is good to take a walk in the National Assembly. You can take a rest for a while after climbing the Uiwon Garden, where the wonderful hanok is located. If it is unfortunate to come to Yeouido and see only the National Assembly, the tour hall of the nearby broadcasting station is also a place that children will like. No reservation is required unless you are in a group.

Capitol facade
Sculpture in front of the capitol
Travel information

* National Assembly Visitor Center
Address: 1 Capitol Road, Yeongdeungpo-gu, Seoul
Contact: 02-788-3656, www.assembly.go.kr

1.Access

* Self-driving

Olympic Boulevard → Yeoui downstream IC → Turn left at the intersection in front of the House of Representatives → Parliament House

* public transport

Get off at National Assembly Building Station (Subway Line 9), and 7-minute walk to Dedicated Museum
City bus 1, 162, 261, 262, 263, 360, 362, 363, 461 and get off in front of the National Assembly Building

2. Delicious

Modagoda: Noodles and Bossam / 30, Gyeok-ro, Yeongdeungpo-gu / 02-786-8787
Other profit press: Thai food / 23, Gukhoe-daero 70-gil, Yeongdeungpo-gu / 02-783-3101
Donghae: Conveyor-belt sushi / 25, Ginkg-ro, Yeongdeungpo-gu / 02-761-6300 / www.donghaedo.com

3.Accommodation

Lexington Hotel: 16, Gukhoe-daero-gil 76-gil, Yeongdeungpo-gu / 02-6670-7000 / http://www.thelexington.co.kr/
Yeouido Hotel: 62, 82, Gwangjin-ro, Yeongdeungpo-gu, 02-782-0121 / http://www.youngdonghotel.co.kr/hotel/korean/index.htm
